alert.note: Alert for Kennebec (Maine) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Flood Warning issued May 03 at 5:45AM EDT until May 03 at 8:00PM EDT by NWS Gray/Portland
info.description: ...The Flood Warning is extended for the following rivers in Maine... New Hampshire... Androscoggin River Near Auburn affecting Androscoggin, Sagadahoc and Cumberland Counties. Suncook River At North Chichester affecting Belknap and Merrimack Counties. Lamprey River Near Newmarket affecting Rockingham and Strafford Counties. ...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Maine... Kennebec River At Augusta affecting Kennebec County. Kennebec River At Skowhegan affecting Somerset and Kennebec Counties. Kennebec River at Hallowell affecting Sagadahoc and Kennebec Counties. ...The Flood Warning is cancelled for the following rivers in Maine... Kennebec River At North Sidney affecting Kennebec County. For the Androscoggin River...including Gorham, Rumford, Auburn... Minor flooding is forecast. For the Kennebec River...including Skowhegan, North Sidney, Augusta, Hallowell...Minor flooding is forecast. For the Suncook River...including North Chichester...Minor flooding is forecast. For the Lamprey River...including Newmarket...Minor flooding is forecast. ...FLOOD WARNING NOW IN EFFECT UNTIL THIS EVENING... * WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast. * WHERE...Kennebec River at Augusta. * WHEN...Until this evening. * IMPACTS...At 12.0 feet, Water begins to flood parking lots on Front Street in Augusta. At 14.0 feet, Water reaches 2 feet deep in parking lots on Front Street in Augusta. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 5:18 AM EDT Wednesday the stage was 13.6 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 5:18 AM EDT Wednesday was 20.4 feet. - Forecast...The river will oscillate above flood stage with a maximum value of 13.7 feet this morning. It will fall below flood stage this afternoon. - Flood stage is 12.0 feet. &&
info.instruction: Please report observed flooding to local emergency services or law enforcement and request they pass this information to the National Weather Service when you can do so safely. Additional information is available at www.weather.gov/gray.
